text: hello everyone thank you all for joining
i'm super excited to be here um because
it is April 1st I do want to say happy
April fools i did not prepare a joke for
you guys but I promise that this talk
will be very serious so thanks um so a
little bit about myself um I'm Pam i'm
an associate at BlackRock and I'm on the
networking team where I focus on
external DNS ingress and the service
mesh and so today I really want to
provide the journey of migrating from a
single cluster model to a multicluster
model with the ISTO service mesh so the
talk today is going to specifically
cover the ISTO open-source uh model and
how we can utilize some open-source
solutions to mitigate some of the
limitations that come with some of those
models and so this is going to be at a
very high level with key considerations
to take into account when implementing
at scale so moving on to the agenda so
first as I mentioned the focus will be
on the ISTO open source deployment
models i'll be covering the networking
model the mesh mesh and identity and the
control plane model i won't be covering
the tenency model but there are options
with the cluster namespace and mesh
tenency
and just how some of the use cases
depending on what features you need for
your multicluster mesh can be considered
with the advantages and disadvantages of
those models and just configuration when
it comes to secrets
etc and then I'll be covering some
challenges this includes like some
configuration complexities it includes
the observability side and it also
includes some life cycle management when
it comes to onboarding new clusters and
decoming other clusters and so the focus
will be on the observability probes this
is going to be on the east west traffic
and also the north south traffic and how
as a platform you want to be alerted
beforehand when you do have applications
that aren't working over your ingress or
over your service mesh to make sure that
you're having that uptime and that
you're not relying on application teams
to go and tell you when there's a
problem and then lastly I'll finish with
ambient and just touching on now that it
is um GA as of ISTO 1.2 24 and so I'll
the model today will be focused on a
sidecar model but with some key
considerations to close out how you can
utilize
ambient so moving on to our network
model so with a network in this case it
is a reference to the workload instances
having direct reachability with each
other so you have different options and
you can mix match these models so with
the single network model this is the
simplest implementation of the network
model and with this model you
essentially have your services that are
not utilizing any ISTO east west gateway
but instead having direct reachability
with each other and so with the single
network model there is another
consideration where this does not allow
for overlapping virtual IP or IP
addresses
however with the multi-et network model
it does have some features that you can
utilize such as the overlapping virtual
IP and IP addresses but also you no
longer have your workload instances
directly reaching each other and you are
utilizing that ISTTO east west gateway
this can be seen as a bottleneck however
one thing I want to call out is in
addition to having those overlapping IP
addresses you have more fault tolerance
with your services being more over
smaller networks rather than one large
network and also it allows for more
segmentation by being able to distribute
these addresses over those smaller
networks and so moving on to the control
plane model so with the control plane in
this case it is the STOD control plane
which is responsible for the
configuration of your services
communicating over the mesh and so your
workload instances will connect to your
STOD control plane and they'll go and
pick up their configuration and so
there's various levels of availability
when it does come to this control plane
implementation that includes across
multiple zones regions clusters and so
from lowest to highest highest
availability you do have that primary
single control plane per your region or
multiple control planes per your region
and then the next level you would have
that single control plane per your zone
or multiple control planes per your zone
and then at the highest availability you
have multiple control planes across your
clusters where each cluster can have its
own control plane and so there are some
advantages to these various levels of
availability
you are able to roll out with more
granular configuration your STOD control
planes and you don't have to worry about
when an STOD goes down having that
impact across the other remote clusters
that or multi- primary clusters that do
have that control
plane and so one thing I do want to
touch on with the highest availability
of having that multi- primary per every
cluster is you do get the additional
benefit benefits of reducing that blast
radius when a control plane does go down
but also when it comes to rollouts of
your deployments for example you with
your tenency let's say you have a client
or business segment to a specific
cluster versus to a shared cluster
perhaps your client cluster can't be
rolled out at a certain release time so
you do have that advantage there but
also there is some things that I want to
point out with the control plane model
and that with the primary remote setup
you can have your remote clusters
connect to your control plane in your
primary cluster or you can have your
remote cluster connect to an external
control plane for example some cloud
vendors may provide this versus in the
multi- primary setup now you have remote
secrets and so with these remote secrets
they essentially have the credentials to
be able to expose these service
endpoints across the Kubernetes API
server and so there is some things I do
want to call out with these remote
secrets one being that when it comes to
the management of these remote secrets
you want to make sure that you are
rotating these secrets and in addition
to rotating these secrets you have to
consider the management of what happens
if they expire the STOD control plane
will temporarily have access for a
little bit before it releases those
endpoints and no longer has access to
those services in your service discovery
in that multi-primary setup and so you
have to take into account the management
but additionally what I do really want
to highlight here is the cons the
security concern when it comes to those
remote secrets because essentially those
remote secrets have access to read all
the secrets across all
namespaces in your multi- primary
cluster so from your hub to your spoke
in your crosscluster and so when it
comes
to your prod environments this most
likely is a no-go because you don't want
to have STOD reading all the secrets
irregardless of if they're specific to
STO secrets so clearly you have more
isolation when it comes to not having to
deploy these remote secrets the other
thing that I do want to call out here is
that when it comes to ISTOD having
access to all your Kubernetes API
servers across your multi- primary setup
STOD essentially needs to have a
reference of the entire state of the
world across all your Kubernetes API
servers and so when you have a
multicluster setup that scales not just
even 50 but hundreds of
clusters can become overwhelmed and
start to crash when it comes to that
scale so you really have to consider the
design of having how you have how many
spokes to a specific hub because you
don't want to overwhelm that hub and you
need to consider that separation when it
does come to that
scale and so moving on to the mesh model
here of course the mesh is model with
the mesh being the infrastructure layer
of the service communication that allows
for that secure and observable
communication again you have the single
mesh model but you also have the
multi-mesh model and it's similar to
this network model in the sense that the
single mesh model is the most simplest
implementation of the mesh model with
the single mesh model you're not having
your services or workload instances
communicate over multiple meshes but
rather in the same mesh and so those
services are unique services there is no
service name or namespace reuse here but
when it comes to the multimesh model you
do have service name and namespace reuse
however your services are now
communicating over different meshes
across different mesh
boundaries and so with this you have to
consider that if your meshes have a
different trust domain then you have to
share trust bundles across those meshes
in order to be able to enable those
services being exposed and so with that
being said that will take us into mesh
and identity shortly after this slide
but with that you do have the extra
management when it comes to the
multimesh model with those benefits of
if you need that use case of that
service name reuse but also if you want
to not have to propagate across one mesh
all services going down if that mesh is
compromised but really keeping that
radius to the services in that mesh so
you don't have to propagate those
issues so moving on to mesh and identity
so here I just want to highlight with
the trust domain starting with the trust
domain so the trust domain is the trust
root of a system and this is used in the
identities when it comes to your ISTO
workload
instances and so with ISTTO you in terms
of certificate authority you have your
rootert your intermediate CA and then
your workload leaferts and so when it
comes to having that authentication and
that ser that secure communication of
your services across a mesh what you'll
need is it will check two things one it
will check does this service have the
certificate of the identity that it is
we are expecting and two is the trust
bundle available so that we can
recognize the identities of the services
that need to be
discovered and so your CA will
essentially create and sign these
certificates in order to create it for
the workload instances
and so with a multi-mesh model each mesh
c can have a different CA and if it does
have a different CA a trust bundle will
be needed to expose those services so I
did mention I wanted to talk about some
open- source solutions
there is spire which is an
implementation of the spiffy identity
which can be utilized where essentially
you have your spire server and your
spire agents and these allow for
workload attestation by assigning these
identities to your workload instances
however one thing that I did want to
call out here is with Spire you could
have some overhead in the sense that
when you do do this at scale you do have
multiple trust bundles that are being
shared across your Spire server and if
you have multiple spokes to a hub that
can again cause some overhead so another
solution could be if you do have an
existing PKI already then utilizing your
external provider you can bring ISTTO
under your root of trust so that by
default ISTTO does have a root
certificate and an immediate CA both
last 10 years but by bringing ISTTO
under your root of trust and utilizing C
manager to automate the rotation of
thoseerts you no longer have to worry
about this convoluted sharing of trust
bundles and having that being exposed
across this multimesh
model and so moving on to some of the
challenges so I mentioned first being
that configuration complexity with the
intricate configurations so independent
applications can have specific needs
maybe an application has specific
headers or specific retry logic or
specific rewrites that they need and so
maybe this requires some additional
envoy filters in order to enable you
don't want to have to lose that
functionality so you have to take that
into consideration but also when it
comes to ensuring that there's
communication that is secure across your
isolated clients I mentioned having a
cluster that is to a specific business
segment you want to make sure that the
communication of that business segment
is not being propagated across other
business segments that shouldn't be
talking to it and then you have
different heterogeneous environments you
can have clusters on prem you can have
clusters in the cloud be it Google
Amazon
Microsoft moving on to the next point we
have life cycle management so it comes
to maintaining and upgrading and
managing STO across your platform
infrastructure like I mentioned maybe
some teams have specific release times
that you need to take into
account there's also the managing of
service discovery across clusters so you
have your service discovery resources
such as your service entries your
virtual services your destination rules
that can be utilized for locality load
balancing when it comes to outlier
detection and so you want to be able to
automate this because you don't want to
have to manually consider doing this for
every single application and then the
third point being as I mentioned
automating cluster life cycle management
when it does come to decoming your old
clusters and bringing on your new
clusters you might have those remote
secrets across your mesh pairs or the
with the multi-primary model your remote
secrets so that also needs to be taken
into
account and then there's observability
when it comes to utilizing metrics and
debugging which I will touch on in the
following slides but one thing that I
did want to highlight here when it comes
to that intricate configuration and that
life cycle management is the usage of
githops be it flux or argo with your
templating tool be it customize or helm
you can utilize githops to do multiple
things you can abstract the logic away
from your application teams because they
don't want to have to f to they
essentially just want to onboard onto
and they don't want to have to configure
all those intricate details and have to
know about
it so when it comes to utilizing GitOps
I mentioned those service discovery
resources with the service entries at
with your host and with the virtual
services with your destination host you
can utilize for bulk onboarding the DNS
name with your wildcard prefix so that
these applications don't individually
need these resources across all the
individual applications and so with this
especially with namespace tenency if you
do have your business segments within a
namespace you don't have to worry about
that manual
configuration and then one thing that I
also wanted to call out is there is the
community project with admiral
which is utilized for the
synchronization across clusters and as I
mentioned with those resources enabling
the deployment of those resources so you
don't have to manually configure that
but the flip side being if you do have
an existing CI/CD pipeline you can
utilize
that and so I'm going to move on to the
observability probes so these
observability probes have been used for
multiple things I do want to call out
that Ki is very useful when it comes to
utilizing that open-source
solution because you're able to see the
ISTTO configuration across your clusters
as well as ISTTO or sorry Kali 2.7 also
released some changes with ambient with
the metrics as well and so you can also
see multicluster it's very useful with
the traffic graph to be able to see your
requests going through but as I
mentioned earlier on the platform side
you don't want to have to wait for
application teams to tell you that there
there's a problem but rather you want to
be alerted beforehand so you can
mitigate that problem and so this
observability probe is a simple go
application and in the architecture
you'll see there is a client and server
this is just for some sample
serviceto-service communication across
the mesh the client will periodically
send pings to the server and the server
will periodically listen and serve to
those pings and send a response
and so with this similar to how you can
configure ISTE metrics with Prometheus
and Grafana the metrics emitted from
this probe we can use as an SLI to
indicate one are services able to
communicate over the mesh but the second
part of this probe being our services
able to register onto the mesh and if
they are able to register onto the mesh
what is the duration of that
registration time and so that is the
registration job where we create that
pod and reach out to the Kubernetes API
server to get the metrics of the init
container time when it comes to the STTO
status but also check that the server
has the mesh enabled labels that is
required to ensure that things are
appropriately set up and so another
thing is this can be utilized with
different mesh types uh this was
actually utilized during a migration uh
of service meshes and so with some
simple simple upstream logic when it
comes to your labels and annotations etc
with your client server you can actually
have different mesh labels to see this
communication if it was utilized during
a migration and I do want to highlight
that this is just one way to do a probe
however your SLI is needed that can also
be utilized um but it is something that
we do often utilize to make sure that
our SLI are being met and we do have
that uptime that we are
expecting and so now we're pushing this
toward the multicluster model where
you'll see that the registration is
still checked within the internal to the
cluster but also there's a change now
with the client and server where the
client is now reaching to its
destination crosscluster pair so or in
this case it's hub and spoke uh internal
and to its crosscluster service and so
the client will send a request ID
request header unique to itself and it
will be passed an upstream and this
upstream again utilizing your templating
tools and GitOps will essentially go and
loop through every single destination to
send to the server and the server will
respond appropriately And so with this
when it comes again to utilizing
Graphfana and Prometheus you can see
with your labels now if there's issues
just not only internal to the cluster
but also from your source and your
destination cluster if there are any
issues occurring and so with this one
thing that needs to be taken into
account with the configuration is you do
have to enable that service discovery
resource when it comes to your service
entries or your virtual services if
utilizing that east west gateway and
that is just the additional logic that's
needed to be able to scale this across
multiple
clusters and so now moving on to the
second probe which is focused on north
south traffic so this probe is
especially useful if you are using an
STTO controller for your gateway
controller and essentially what happens
is we will generate a host name and this
host name because it is periodically
generated it will check if there is a
pre-existing instance of that host name
because we don't want duplicates if
there is it will delete it and then it
will create an A record to the DNS
server and it will do a lookup on that
DNS server after creation and check am I
is this record available am I able to do
a lookup utilize with external DNS then
it will send a request through the
gateway to that host name to verify the
second check which is is traffic able to
go through the
ingress and so this ensures that we can
consistently monitor the monitor the
availability of external DNS and our
ingress and one thing that I also wanted
to call out here is at scale you don't
want to overwhelm your DNS servers so
when it does come to the generation of
those A records to your DNS server you
can use some job randomization logic and
some retry logic so that you're not
consistently creating a records all the
time to overwhelm it and so I do want to
say this is a very broad architecture
with ingress you can use it with an STTO
gateway with your virtual services or
you can use it with the Kubernetes
gateway API with routes it's not
specific to any specific it's not
specific to any
ingress and so lastly I do want to end
with ambient um ambient is essentially
it breaks the L4 and L7 traffic so that
you don't essentially you have a Z
tunnel with your name spaces that are
using that L4 traffic but then you have
a waypoint with your L7 traffic for
those specific services or subset of
services that do need to use L7 and so
this can cut overhead because you no
longer have to worry about setting your
resources when it comes to your ISTO
sidecars specifically with the ISTO
sidecars there has been cases where
application teams have had applications
that had an increase in their load and
so the envoy sidecar would be
overwhelmed and there would be a crash
because it was maxed on its limits and
with its CPU and memory and so they had
to go and see okay this is being maxed
let me go and reconfigure so that can be
an issue but ambient cuts that overhead
and so there is one thing that I wanted
to call out here with the road map of
ambient is taking into consideration
with that road map the interoperability
when it comes to ambient and sidecar so
you can slowly try and migrate to the
ambient when it comes to adding new hub
and spokes specific to your cluster uh
but you want to essentially make sure
that when you do do a migration this is
taken into account with wanting to
enable that interoperability as there's
continuous advancements being made
toward it and so with that I just want
to say thank you all so much it's been a
pleasure and please reach out um I've
had a great time speaking to you all
today
[Applause]
